At least 114 journalists were killed in sometimes gruesome cir- cumstances, making it the deadliest year for reporters ever, Aidan White, secretary-general of the In- ternational Federation of Journalists, said yesterday. At least 114 journalists were killed in sometimes gruesome cir- cumstances, making it the deadliest year for reporters ever, Aidan White, secretary-general of the In- ternational Federation of Journalists, said yesterday.

The Brussels based federation this year registered "at least 114 con- firmed cases of violent death, some in g uesome circumstances," he said, adding that 15 other killings and re- ports of journalists gone missing were still being investigated. The Brussels based federation this year registered "at least 114 con- firmed cases of violent death, some in g uesome circumstances," he said, adding that 15 other killings and re- ports of journalists gone missing were still being investigated.

P Twelve journalists and five other members of news teams were also killed in accidents while doing on- the-spotreporting. P Twelve journalists and five other members of news teams were also killed in accidents while doing on- the-spotreporting.

In 1991, a federation tally had spoken of 84 dead worldwide. This year, more than half of all journalists died while reporting on the ethnic unrest in Rwanda and on Algeria's violent showdown between Moslem fundamentalists and the military-backed government. In 1991, a federation tally had spoken of 84 dead worldwide. "But the mafia and political ter- rorists also claimed their toll, notably in Russia and Latin America where journalists have been brutally assassi- nated," said White. The federation plans to provide guidelines for journalists' safety to en- courage the media, unions and government to act. The federation plans to provide guidelines for journalists' safety to en- courage the media, unions and government to act.

Such guidelines would include better information and training for jour- nalists travelling to crisis areas, along with pressure put on employers to provide better insurance and social security cover. Such guidelines would include better information and training for jour- nalists travelling to crisis areas, along with pressure put on employers to provide better insurance and social security cover.
Government must acknowledge that journalists' security is more and more at risk, said White. Government must acknowledge that journalists' security is more and more at risk, said White.

"Freedom of the press is not, in terms of democracy, a marginal prob- lem because without freedom of the press, there is no democracy", said White. "Freedom of the press is not, in terms of democracy, a marginal prob- lem because without freedom of the press, there is no democracy", said White.

AIDS Kill More Women - Study AIDS Kill More Women - Study

Women are more likely to die faster from AIDS than men, according to a new study. The report appearing in Wednesday's Journal of the American Medical Association found women with AIDS were 33 per cent more likely to die than men who had comparable states of the illness. Sandra Melnick of the University of Minnesota led the 15-month study of 768 women and 3,779 men infected with the AIDS virus. Although women make up only about 15 per cent of those infected with the AIDS virus, the number is growing and "we're still way behind in reaching women at risk," said Renslow Sherer, director of Chicago's Cook Country HIV Primary Care Center. Thesurvey results suggest women may receive different care for AIDS or wait longer than men to seek treatment, researchers said. Women are more likely to die faster from AIDS than men, according to a new study. The report appearing in Wednesday's Journal of the American Medical Association found women with AIDS were 33 per cent more likely to die than men who had comparable states of the illness. Sandra Melnick of the University of Minnesota led the 15-month study of 768 women and 3,779 men infected with the AIDS virus. Although women make up only about 15 per cent of those infected with the AIDS virus, the number is growing and "we're still way behind in reaching women at risk," said Renslow Sherer, director of Chicago's Cook Country HIV Primary Care Center. Thesurvey results suggest women may receive different care for AIDS or wait longer than men to seek treatment, researchers said.
Hostages Stay Traumatised For Years, Psychiatrists Warn Hostages Stay Traumatised For Years, Psychiatrists Warn

The trauma for people held hostage by terrorists or common criminals may for years unless treatment is given immediately after their release, psychiatrists said in Paris. In recognition of these long-term effects, Air France has taken steps to provide psychological support for the released hostages from the 24-hour the Airbus hijack drama which began in Algeris Monday and ended with successful storming of the aircraft yesterday in Marseille. "A hijack is an act of war in peace-time and therefore we have used said our Dr. Marie-Claude Dentan, Air France's specialist in the treatment of acute stress. experience of battlefield trauma and adapted it to civilian circumstances," "The most important thing is to provide follow-up by looking after the ex. hostages needs and showing them that we care about them," she said. Tuesday, Air France organised in Marseille, then at Orly airport in Paris a buffer In an attempt to dedramatise the situation for the 170 hostages freed for the passengers and their families. Doctors, psychiatists and other specialists were on hand to listen as people recounted what they had gone through and what they felt. "We had to do everything to enable the hijack victima to 'launder their not memories' and put into words the ordeal they suffered so memories will be pushed back and allowed to 'fester in their minds'," Dr. Dentan said. The next stage involved asking the ex-hostages to "describe" the event VICHIME psychologists and psychiatrists. A list of centresspecialised in treating trauma in Paris civilian and military hospitals was given to each passenger, she said. Mandela's Lieutenant Suffers Heart Former African National Congress (ANC) deputy president has been admitted to hospital in Johnnesburg suffering from failure," a hospital spokesman said yesterday. Sisulu, regarded as President Nelson Mandela's right-hand yesterday to Johannesburg from Eastern Transvaal province, where on Monday during a visit to Kruger Park game reserve. He was brought to Morningside clinic in Johannesburg's suburb by helicopter yesterday afternoon, followed after Albertina, also an ANC veteran, who looked ashen-faced. On emerging from the clinic's intensive care unitsome brighter Mrs. Sisulu said her husband was in a stable condition suffering from "fatigue and stress." The clinic spokeswoman said Sisilu's condition was stable yesterday "sitting up in bed having supper." Sisulu spent 26 years in prison alongside Mandela for sabotage against the former white minority South African regarded as the president's closest confidante. claim Mandela seldom makes without Political reference commentators to Sisulu, with whom'he helped form the in the 1940s. Both men cut their political teeth on the ANC's campaigns the the white authorities in the 1940s and 1950s and rose eventually head the anti-apartheid movement. Before he was jailed in 1946, Sisulu held the position of ANC general. On his release in October 1989, he resumed active months later was elected the ANC's deputy president this He held the post until the ANC's three-yearly conference from when he announced his retirement from the ANC but not against apartheid.
